I'm intrigued as to why your depreciation expense actually hasn't moved, and on a potentially sales basis is down 30 bps.

Yes. I'm not sure percentage of sales would be the way that I'd be looking at depreciation, but in relation – I think in relation to the divisions we've put a split there of the land and buildings that are out. And you can see that's quite a large amount. You can also see that in relation to a lot of the CapEx, David, in resources, for instance you've got big work-in-progress amounts as we go and, if you like, construct an asset that might take you 12 months to construct.

So I think you've got to look at construction time frames as well as within those PP&E amounts, because you're going to have big whip swings, and I think the only thing we can say in terms of across those divisions you mentioned, is there's been no change in depreciation practices or policies in relation to our group policies. So it is what it is.

So would I be correct, then, in saying that the – for example the significant increase that we're seeing in Bunnings capital employed is primarily land or stores that are in construction at the moment?
We've made that clear that the network, the pipeline of stores that we've got and the network expansion has been a -
Hello?
Highlight to that division now for a couple of years, at least.
Sorry, I didn't hear any of that.
Yeah, sure. A longer way of saying yes.
Okay. Thank you.
Our next question will come from Grant Saligari of Credit Suisse. Please go ahead, sir.
My question has been answered. Thanks.
Our next question will be from David Errington of Merrill Lynch. Please go ahead.

Good afternoon, all. Richard, my question is on – I suppose, to Stewart Butel, on coal, and the ability to be able to participate in what may be a price spike between, say, April and June. I think I heard him say that he's got some carryover tonnes he has to deliver into, and I'm trying to get an understanding as to what the volume schedule is likely to look like at Curragh, when they'll be able to get back up to a reasonable production level, and what the arrangements are with customers in delivering inter-prices that could potentially spike?
You can be sure we're asking the same question, David. But I'll hand over to Stewart.

Yeah, I'll answer that in two parts, David, and thanks for the question. As you know, that I've indicated in the slide pack that the full impact on – of the flooding will happen in this March quarter, and – so looking at that, we'll have deliveries at Q – this current quarter that won't be delivered in this current quarter, so that will go into Q4. And we're currently under force majeure at the moment with our customers. And as we lift force majeure, as we get back to full production, there will be a negotiation on what carryover tonnage would apply, and also clearly what the coal prices will be for Q4, and for the annual tonnage that settles at that same time. Our best estimate at the moment is that we'll have carryover into Q4, and that will be approximately four to six weeks of production. So, that's somewhere between a third and a half of Q4 sales will be at carryover prices.

So do you get the – like say – let's just pick a number, say the price spikes to $400 for that quarter, and I'm not suggesting that's what it will be, but let's just call it that, does that mean that you only get a half a quarter's tonnage at that price, and then it finishes, or does that then carry over into the next quarter?

Well, each quarter is based on an agreed volume. So, say it is agreed at, I'd say, a $250 number, David, just getting a bit more pessimistic on coal prices, say it's $250, then that $250 would apply for the – say, in this case, if it's six weeks of carryover, the second half of Q4 -
Yeah.
...and would extend into Q1 of next year for half of Q1.

Yeah. And given that the market's fairly tight – I mean, not that you want to do your customers, but suppliers are in a pretty good condition here, aren't they, and you're all in the same boat with this carryover tonnage situation?

Yet. Look, I suppose my comment on the market, David, to be a bit more specific, is the market is very, very tight at the moment, as you can imagine. All of the Queensland export metallurgical coal producers have been impacted by this major flood event and cyclone Yasi. At the same time, we're seeing Canadian producers, particularly Teck with quite a lot of industrial problems with production, and production out of Russia is also impacted as well. So, coal is very, very tight.

The only producer out there that's probably got excess capacities is the U.S. We are seeing very, very strong demand from all our traditional customers in this – since over the last 12 months, there's been new production come online in Korea, Taiwan and Brazil. And at the moment spot prices are very healthy, in the case of high coking coal they're up around $350 to $380.
Yeah.
So the outlook looks very positive. But as I said before, we're yet to roll into that price negotiation. That will happen before the end of March, and that will ultimately set the marketplace.

Thanks, Stewart. And my second question, before I get cut off, is to Launa, and I suppose to Guy, but I was a little bit, Launa, taken aback by the 26% drop in profit. I knew it was a very tough half for you, but your gross margin was down, yet Kmart's gross margin was up. I was a little bit perplexed as to why one could be down and one could be up.

I suppose my question, Launa, is how much of the drop in the EBIT was a factor of – you probably over earned last year, and it's coming back to more normal levels, but how much of that was due to that fact, and how much was due to maybe tough trading conditions? And was there anything in the half that maybe you didn't do well that you could probably have done better, that you might do better going forward?

All right. So, I'll firstly break that into three parts. Firstly, I'm first to acknowledge that the great result last year was a phenomenal anomaly. And I do remember calling out to you that it was a wonderful result, but I didn't think we could do it again. Putting that aside, there's a number of issues. The biggest one for us has been deflation, and it's been particularly obvious in our apparel, which of course for our business that's our key competencies for Target. But as I said earlier, it has been right across the whole business.

And secondly, we found we were very badly hit with our real seasonal stock, particularly ladies' wear, which is very important for us. And I have to say, David, some of that was due to probably our own making, not necessarily with the range not necessarily being ideal. We also did take a punt on a couple of things, because we had had an out of stock some real high seasonal products the previous year, we actually made the decision to back it a little bit more when it came to things like beach towels, deck chairs, a bit more swimwear, which unfortunately didn't pay dividends this time. The weather went against us, and particularly where a lot of that product is driven by Queensland for us.

So, there was an element of some of it beyond our control, but also, I have to say, possibly some of it our own making that maybe we just didn't get the range 100% right, and we probably also were a little over optimistic initially.
Thanks, Launa.
Next question will come from Andrew McLennan from The Commonwealth Bank. Please go ahead, sir.

Good afternoon. Just a maybe quick question in relation to Coles EBIT margins. Another strong result, but you've had in the first half of this year stronger comparable sales growth, but at the same time you mention in your outlook statement that the competitive environment is becoming an issue, that you've actually separated out, which you haven't done before. I would have imagined that the level of competition hasn't changed in its intensity in the last 12 months, but are you suggesting that it has increased in the last six months, or is it going to increase further from here?

I think the market's always been competitive, but clearly our results are an outperformance of the market, and I would expect people to recognize that and look to claw back some additional sales growth, perhaps early expense. What I have said in the past is that there's 30,000 competitors out there, not just one or two, and our strategy has been about driving value and driving quality in fresh foods as well. So, I think that it's always important as a retailer to be cognizant of market changes and competitive impact, but it's also to remain focused on your underlying strategy.

And what we've endeavored to do right the way through here is focus on value to get customers through the door, increase sales, fractionalize costs, utilize the efficiencies that we're gaining now back to investing further and try to deliver further sales growth on the back of that. And the combination of the sales growth that were coming through and improved efficiencies is leading us to the position where we're growing comparable store sales, but also have an option to improve profitability as well. And that's been part of our plan. And we know that things will get tougher, but we're being resolute to improve further going forward.

Okay. And just in relation to easy ordering, you've progressed very well rolling it out within the Coles stores. At the end of FY '12, will you look to extend easy ordering into the department stores, and potentially into Bunnings? Is that an option?

Andrew, I mean each business is quite different, and the intensity of product flow through Coles is quite different to the other businesses. They've got their own supply chain initiatives, but I don't think they'll be piggybacking on what Coles has done.
And it wouldn't be appropriate for Kmart either?
No.
No. Okay, thanks.
Thanks.
Next question will come from Richard Barwick from Hunter Green. Please go ahead.

Hi, everybody. I know this has been touched on a little bit already. I just want to talk about – if you could give a breakdown on the value of the freehold property that currently sits on the balance sheet and, in particular, how much of that would be attributed to supermarkets and how much to Bunnings?
We'll look it up for you -
Yeah.
...Richard, if we can.

And I'm not sure we'll split it out anyway. What we give is publicly available. I mean, the easiest way to do that is if you go to our full year results announcement and we've given you how much we've spent in the half with land and buildings and add the two together and that tells you how much our land and buildings are but we won't split that out by division.

Okay. What I was particularly interested in is the Bunnings outcome where they've got a 40 bps margin expansion but then their return on capital has actually gone backwards. I was just trying to get a sense of where that return might have been in a more normalized property outcome.
I think John alluded to that originally. I think he talked a bit about the transactions that's been announced today with the trust and that will have a positive impact on ROIC.

We measure ROC on a rolling 12 basis Richard and at the moment we haven't completed a major sale and lease-back transaction since the 2007 transaction. These things are lumpy. You'd love to do it in a way that you could match it perfectly, but you have to be very cognizant to market conditions, particularly for sale and lease-back. Whereas on the acquisition side, the significant change that occurred in the property sector post the GFC meant that we weren't able to really use developers and the developers lacked the capital to develop our stores.

That's a negative but a bigger positive actually came up which was that more sites were available at really quite exciting prices and we've worked very hard since that 2008 timeframe to take that opportunity and you're really starting to see the fruit of that work coming through and our property team is doing a terrific job. And the pace we've got on building our store pipeline's really quite exciting because the quality of it – the sort of sites we've got and what we're able to execute when we bring big stores on – is very exciting.

Hopefully with some more sale and lease-back transactions now that there seems to be some more appetite for that across the market will see us manage our capital better so that we get our ROC going in the right direction matching what we're doing in terms of earnings and other business performance.

Okay. The second question is to you, Ian. You referred to the management strength and depth at Coles. Can you give any sort of comment around the – I guess the longevity of that? What I'm interested in to get a sense for is obviously there's been a lot of publicity around what level, say within your top 200 managers at Coles had been imports, how long are they able to stay for, how long do you think they'll stay or what's the mix of Aussies versus ex-pats in the top 200?

Richard, let me take that initially and then I'll hand over to Ian. I think it's completely irrelevant what the mix might be because it depends that we're talking first generation, second generation or fifth generation.
Because as you look around, as you look around this, when we -
Maybe I'll answer a little bit crudely. Richard, really what I wanted to get at is, you're saying there's management strength and depth.
Yes, there is.
That's today, how are we placed on a three and five-year route?

I think we're placed superbly well because what Ian and the team have done – one of the things we said when we first acquired Coles was we need to build a world-class top management team. We've done that but importantly and what people haven't had a lot of visibility on is that team has now put in place an exceptional team below it and further through the organization.

And we've got those people from all over the place including Australia but importantly they've been recruited based on their competency and based on their desire to come to Australia and be part of the turnaround which we indicated to the market at the time of the acquisition in order to get time from the capital market to effect a sustained turnaround – was a five-year turnaround.
But in our mind this is a 15 to 20 year project and I think for the vast majority of people who've joined Coles they've joined it as a career project and they intend to be here for a long time.
I'm not certain we've got limitations on timeframes for any of the employees we've got in Coles but Ian can take it from there.

I mean, Richard's pretty much said everything as well. I mean, really we're not that interested in employing people for short-term positions. We're in for developing the business for the long-term. I think Wesfarmers' track record is one where they hold assets for a long period of time and the whole point about the turnaround was a timeframe of five years was set because that realistically was how long it was going to take to turn around basically two decades of decay.

And in this kind of environment that would be a reasonable timeframe to expect. It's not just a question of getting to give years and then the job being done. This is a long-term program to rebuild a sustainable business and a great brand and we're pleased with the progress that we're making and I'm delighted with the quality of people that go into the organization from whatever country and they're here for the long haul.

A lot of people that have come internationally are actually seeing it as a lifestyle change as well and an opportunity to grow and develop their careers and clearly whilst we've started to make some progress then there's broader levels of interest about people coming in and joining the organization because they see the opportunities both for themselves in terms of professionally but also in terms of living in Australia. Even Melbourne for a Scot actually is a pretty nice place to be.
So Richard, I wouldn't be concerned about a mass exodus at any sort of five year anniversaries of either of the acquisition or of people who started work at Coles.

No, well, that's exactly what I was getting at. I just want to get some comfort that at the end of the five years they're not going to pack up their pencil cases and go home so you've answered that, thank you.
Thanks Richard.
Next question will come from Greg Dring from Macquarie. Please go ahead, sir.
Okay, thank you. Terry, I may have missed your responses but did you call out the adjustment to the Coles EBIT for both the useful life adjustment and for the meat contract?

For the meat contract we did not. I mean, useful life is not an adjustment because a useful life effectively was assets that weren't in, if you like, IT assets that were still in WIP that we effectively adjusted on completion. There's an amount in there but it's just depreciation and its consistent depreciation and it's not relevant to call it out and adjust it against previous periods because it wasn't there.
But there is a consolidation adjustment each period going through?
Yes, there is but in the scheme of things it's -
What, about 50 million or 50 million bucks a year?

It's not as high as that Greg and it's come down obviously but the issue is to put it in there it's like calling out another piece of depreciation. It's just depreciation and it's not relevant relative to looking back in history in Coles' ownership because it wasn't there.
Okay, so the only adjustment we need to consider is the fair value adjustment of 30 something, is that it?
Yes, that's right.
Okay.
Meat was 24, Greg. I think Terry called out.
Yes, 24.
Okay, okay. So the 24 and the 32 or something.
It's not as high as that. As you said, it's like – anyway -

Okay, I get the answer. My second question is to Ian. Ian, I wonder if there's any limitations to the use of the half price KVI strategy and the limitations, I'm wondering whether you'd discuss would be declining velocity uplift from – as your cycle when you first introduce them, compromising trust of customers going forward or just even the financial burden of using such a strategy?

Any investments we make, Greg, are carefully planned and considered over a period of time. So I wouldn't like to give the impression that this is something that we thought up on a Monday and implemented on Tuesday. We've been very careful about our overall plan for two and three years and that will continue. What we are seeing is we've been rewarded with the changes that we've made and the improvements that we've made and it's broadening the customer base, it's broadened the basket base.

And therefore, everything that we're doing is considered both in terms of the impact it has on that product category and also what we expect to happen in the basket and the overall foot traffic. So we're very pleased with the progress that we're making and the investments we're making and where we're putting them.
Next question will come from Shaun Cousins of JPMorgan. Please go ahead, sir.

Thanks. My question's for Ian. Just in regards to Coles, when do you see EBIT margin expansion as a bigger contributor to EBIT growth rather than the very strong sales growth that you're getting because I'm conscious that you're only generating a return on capital of 7.1%. Dollar EBIT is going to be a key catalyst to get you there but eventually I can't see you getting to your cost of capital to a decent return on capital unless you get some still significant margin expansion. So when do you think margin expansion will be a bigger driver than sales?

Well, I've never given an indication about where our ultimate EBIT margin will get to but clearly as we go through the program, there's an expectation that margin will continue to improve and we're well aware of that and that's what we'd expect to see happen. In terms of the mix on sales growth, I wouldn't necessarily get the two of them confused because nobody really knows what's going to happen to inflation going forward or the overall cycling of where you are.

What's important is the underlying health of the business and as a result of the changes that we've been making, we're getting improvements in efficiencies and we've still got more to come. So we're pretty confident that we can continue to improve our profitability over time.
Shaun, we're really focused on EBIT dollars and obviously for the transaction cash generation over time.

Yes. I mean I think that's part of the reason for the question. I mean to grow your EBIT dollars you're going to need to expand margins as well. Maybe another metric; how do you guys see the 7.1% return on capital where you need to be now that you've gone over the halfway mark of the five year sort of turnaround? Is that sort of ahead of where you're expecting? Below? How do you see that 7.1% return on capital?
Well, we see it as an improvement but there's a fair way to go.
I was going to say it was exceptional but Richard got in there first.
It's below cost of capital, so that's exceptional. Thanks very much.
Thanks, Shaun.
Next question comes from Phil Kimber of Godman Sachs. Please go ahead, sir.
I was wondering if you could make any comment on trading so far in the back half of the financial year for the retail businesses.

I touched on this a bit a few weeks ago, Phil, and I think we said at the time there's good momentum in Coles and in the other retail businesses. I think we've seen a slight improvement in conditions over the last four or five weeks but I underline slight.

Okay. And then another one on the $40 million to $50 million damaged plant and inventory, that's all second half, so that doesn't include the $20 million self insurance that you took in the first half?
No, that's all second half.

Okay. And maybe – I mean that's maybe more than what I thought and then there's the $30 million to $40 million business interruption on top of that. Can you give a sense of how many stores have actually been impacted?

Well, you've just got to look at the photos of stores like a lot of our stores around Emerald which were completely immersed in water to realize it doesn't take too many of those. I think there were all up 70 something stores in the group that were impacted by the floods and we've still got a number, a handful or so, that aren't open across Coles and Bunnings I think. So I mean we've got a Target store in Emerald that's in a warehouse somewhere now. So if you think about the network we've got in that part of the world it was a fairly significant impact.

Okay. And the $30 million to $40 million is the business interruption, why they're getting – not open. Once they're opened that doesn't then include any of the business interruption? Obviously the store might be open but people have still got other issues going on and can't get to the store, so I just wasn't sure how you define business interruption.

At this stage, it would cover everything but not normal trading. So that's the best way to describe it, so it would be broader than what you've just referred to there. And supply chain has been a big – particularly in Coles has been a big, if you like additional cost because of obviously a lot of the roads being inaccessible and having to use alternate sources which are often expensive.
Okay. Thanks.
Thanks.
Next question will come again from Daniel Broeren of RBS. Please go ahead.
Just before you go ahead, Daniel, we'll just try and make questions and answers quick. We're going to bring this to a close in a minute, so.

No problem. Just in relation to your comments on the dividend earlier, that you've taken a cautious approach given the cash flow outlook. Does that mean that you'll still aim to deliver a payout ratio on a full year basis close to 70% if everything goes right in the back half?

I don't think we've ever indicated payout ratios. We talk about yes, stable and growing dividends and what we look at is, amongst other things, cash flow, cash position, what our forecast capital expenditure is, level of franking credits. There's a bunch of things and, as I said, when you set an interim dividend, typically, we've sort of erred on the cautious side of things.
Okay. Thanks.
Thanks.
Next question will come from David Cooke of Nomura. Please go ahead, sir.

Hi, there, just looking at the Coles and the Bunnings businesses in particular, can you give us an indication please as to how much of your EBIT margin improvement was gross margin-related versus cost of doing business-related? Was it more weighted towards one than the other in each business?

Well, I'm not going to really go into great detail on that, David, but I think that all I will do is point to what I've said before which is we're looking to improve our costs of doing business. Clearly, there were opportunities for us to look at levels of investment and price that were supported by supplier base and also supported by ourselves, so there's a combination there.

So in overall terms there's a mix effect which is actually borne out now really driving higher levels of efficiency out of the business that we can continue to invest. Clearly if suppliers are seeing broad levels of volumes coming out of the organization as a result of what we're doing then they themselves are more prepared to invest in that change as well.
And Bunnings?

Just to add to what Ian said, there's a similar flavor inside Bunnings. I'd point also to driving the productivity loop very hard. We've created a lot of additional value very purposely. That has a deflationary impact but it also makes your cost base work harder and that gives you good productivity gains. And with the volumes you're able to generate, that gives a much stronger bond with the suppliers that are participating. So it's a combination of good things that sort of flow around a halo effect really as you can get that working for you.
And sorry just on, Ian, if you then look at the EBIT gross margin side, would you say that it's more your volume metric rather than say a product mix that drove any gross margin expansion?
I'm probably not going to help you very much there either because I'm going to say it's both as well.
Next question will come from Greg Dring of Macquarie. Please go ahead, Greg.

Thanks. Just a quick one. Looking at the differing performances of Target and Kmart, I'm just wondering whether the respective business leaders there sort of compare foot traffic through shopping centres and if there's any evidence that suggests that there was actually less foot traffic in shopping centres or the performance of the brands is really a function of the brand rather than activity in the shopping centre?

Greg, it's really difficult to comment on that. It depends to an extent by a shopping centre. I know Guy has some very good foot traffic and we certainly have seen an increase in customers coming into our stores but it's been also driven by states and it's been inconsistent and a lot of it, of course, is dependent on the weather. Guy, do you want to comment on that?

I haven't seen any reduction in foot traffic in the shopping centres. There's a big parcel of stores that Kmart have got that are freestanding on their own with Coles that used to be part of the super centres. So those particular stores are growing at a similar rate to the ones that are inside the shopping centres as well. So I think the consumer's out there shopping and, as everyone's been pointing out around the table, they're shopping for value.
Okay.
Next question will come from Craig Woolford of Citigroup. Please go ahead.

Hi guys, just a quick on Kmart's inventory. I think there was a comment that suggested that inventory had increased. Obviously direct sourcing's an impact but given lower price points, deflation from Aussie dollar benefits, can you just give some sense as to why it's increased?

There's a lot more volume going through the stores, Craig, with the focus on -now that we've got out of all the products that we've been talking about in the last 12 months, the big and bulky loss makers and high end products in the range, our volume has increased significantly. And we are sourcing significantly more product ourselves from our own sourcing agent in China and Bangladesh and Hong Kong. So there's a lot more stock that we – not significantly a lot more but more stock that we need to hold, especially on the water to ensure that we've got the correct amount of volume that our customers are putting into their baskets.

Right. But stock turns would be up if your volumes are so much stronger but you're obviously holding more safety stock at the moment. Is there an opportunity for this inventory to come down over the next 18 months or so?

Yes, I mean what you saw in the last 12 months was a significant drop in inventory as we changed or switched models, if you like, in a period of the year. We're learning how to operate this everyday low price model and, at the same time, reducing costs. So I think we've got a little bit of a buffer in there because we're not relying on local suppliers to carry that inventory in their warehouses here in Australia.

So there might be a little bit extra. But I'd rather saw that the good part about that inventory, it's good stock and because we're focusing on everyday items it's not special promotional stock. It's products that consumers want which is perfect with our strategy of everyday items for their homes that they need for their homes and for their families.
Okay. Thank you.
Thanks, Craig.
There are no further questions from the telephones. At this point, I'd like to hand back to Mr. Goyder.
Well, thank you all very much. And if you've got any follow-up questions, please contact Alex, otherwise have a good day.
That concludes our teleconference for today. Thank you for participating. You may now disconnect.
